Fw: Contains my opinion of autism and ADHD (non-professional)

Nathan could be a case of autism. He seems like a great kid, I just feel that autism may be misconstrued as just being ADHD in modern diagnoses. I feel as if there is a stigma towards autism (in this context, its diagnosis), there's a bias in which practitioners would rather claim a child has ADHD rather than the more "serious" identification of autism. Autism, to me, is a condition which I have a familiar relationship with- especially the negative connotation which parallels the diagnoses. ADHD is a condition which can, and typically does, require a lesser load of therapeutic treatment- a deficiency which is supplemented by newer pharmaceuticals such as vyvanse and adderall. I am completely unqualified to speak upon the effects of such drugs on a developing mind, and can therefore not speak on their effects, but the topic concerns me. I worry about children being misdiagnosed, as having ADHD rather than their true condition which strips the child of receiving the personal treatment of which they are entitled to.

As someone who was given a so called die month's I can say the first two or three months was extremely hard. Not only was I in extreme pain from fighting two primary cancers squamous cell carcinoma that spread to my bones (terminal) and endometrial cancer that had also spread to other layers and organs it was freaking painful and scary. Granted I am now in remission after 4 years and once I crossed over the 12 months die date it didn't make it that much easier be of the pain but also they had given me medication to turn my mind off which I hated because it changed me and it also made me not able to talk which is not something you really want to happen when you feel you have a few months to a year to live. Before I had even known my cancer was gone I was ok if I died. You can say it could have been with my level of pain and how much cancer I had which was a crap ton. I had cancer from the top of my head to both my knees in every bone and so many tumors on my ovaries, endometrial lining that had eaten through the wall so I had a lot of cancer. I had to have many surgeries before even getting radiation like on my hip. I had to get a partial hip replacement and to think just 6 months prior to this I was running 6 to 10 miles a day. My one ovary was bleeding internally so my iron crashed to 2.6 and my hair and nails were falling out and off. I didn't eat for a month and my stomach wasn't growling because my body had shut down to bare minimum to try to save my vital organs. I was having seizures and one stroke because of my iron levels. I faught two months in the bed and bath tub because I was alone and lived a few hours from family and for a while I thought it was my autoimmune diseases because I have 5 at that time and by the time it got so bad I was going in and out of consciousness. I guess the pain for me after so long made it easier for me to accept my death along with the burden of knowing my mom was getting up in age and I didn't want her to spend her life taking care of me because I got to the point I was in the bed all day and night and it took every once I had to get up and shower for Dr's appt. My body was so tired. I was tired but for some reason I lived and not with a lot of treatments either and I know so many no longer believe in God but I surely do. That's why I don't believe in all this technology when it comes to bringing people back to life. I know it's just my opinion and I'm fine to have that opinion but what happens when people no longer have the right to their opinions any longer because you would be too perfect for a science experiment and don't fool yourself to think that want happen because I'm sure it already has.

I don't like how they talked about testing placebos with "nonverbal autistic kids" because they "don't have the understanding/context of colors and themes" (loosely quoting). Nonverbal does not mean unintelligent. There are so many issues with this way if thinking. There are ways to communicate outside of verbal language. So many autistic people communicate through sign language or computers. And so many autistic people are never given these tools to communicate because people assume they can't. This is such a damaging misconception. Beyond the communication side of this, even people with intellectual disabilities (often co-morbid with autism, but are not part of autism) have the ability to understand the world around them. There is far more going on inside disabled people's minds than people assume.

michael brings up the potential stubborness of the "super mature people" whove had their lives extended towards potential social progress, and how it could be an issue, and not one that he necessarily believes means those people deserve to die. its a serious ethical question, and one we dont have to usually contend with, but not because we dont face that problem.

i think the word boomer is obviously overused due to memetic adoption. but, i also think its only overused because its applicable. often, the most opposed to social changes and social movements, are the older population. not all the time, obviously, as many of those elders themselves want this change. for instance, older gay people who lived through the aids crisis still support pride and the fight for lgbt rights. but they arent the only ones who are old, and the loudest voices, and sometimes most represented opinions, come from those older people who opposed these things in the past, just as strongly as they do now.

social change is possible in part, due to people being raised with different values and enviroments. those different values and enviroments likely came from other, past social changes. i personally believe that as much as changing the minds and opinions of the opposition leads to this, the death of the older population does contribute to this. and not always in a positive way mind you. the death of guidance from the past can lead to past mistakes being repeated. to people not learning important lessons, and important view points. much like michael, i am obviously not advocating genocide, nor do i believe i or anyone else can or should be the augur of whether someone should live, based solely on their value set. but its a question we dont often have to deal with. and even if we think about it, at least in the current state of things, its not one where the answers we arrive at even matter. the elderly will die. everyone will die. we dont have to tackle the ethicality of an older persons death based upon their belief system, because we are not the ones who have a say in it. they will die regardless. how we feel after is in our control, but you cant really invalidate someones feelings.

for instance. i dont have to think about whether or not i believe my grandfather deserves to continue living. i dont want him to die, and i know for a fact that when the inevitable happens, i will be devestated. at the same time, i cant say there are aspects and attributes about him that i wont miss. the man can be incredibly racist towards a wide, wide variety of people. hes also incredibly controlling, and dismissive of his own family when they display a certain resistance to what he thinks they should do. ive witnessed both things plenty of times. i dont hate him, but i have been very angry with his behaviour and beliefs. but i dont have to decide the value of his life on those things i get mad at him for. and it wont make his passing less sad.

michaels point brings up an interesting lesson, at least for me. there is something to be said for human death to be unavoidable and uncontrolable by us, specifically because when we give ourselves the power to control life and death, we give ourselves the power to decide who should live, and who should die. alcors mission statement and message is that they arent creating immortals, just creating a new way to save someone from death, the same as say, the covid 19 vaccine. but there is a reason people find pharma companies refusing to release the patent on the vaccine for free evil. theres a reason that many countries try to distribute it for free. its a life saving measure, so it should save all lives, regardless of who it saves. and when it only saves some people, and for incredible cost no less, than its not a brand new life saving measure so much as its the saver of some lives.

Michael, not sure if you will actually read this or not, but in addition to asking the test subjects if they believed positively in the theory behind the study, you should also get feedback from anyone that thinks that maybe the opposite effect was true, or that the theory of the researchers was wrong and why. It might help to develop falsifiable theories as well as get insights for future attempts or research along the same lines. If you are coming clean with the test subjects, this is always something worth considering as it will help the researchers devise better scenarios and perhaps even give them ideas for coming up with more and more appropriate controls.

I'd be interested in a methodical study of the effects of revealing the deceptive nature of the treatment to a recipient after a positive response. Not to be an asshole, but to see if it's cognitive or latent influence that works. This would include how their view develops, are they able to suspend disbelief and still benefit.

I feel that for the TMT experiment, it would be more useful to see how often people go to the extremes. For example, a 4 could have a value of 1, a 3 or 5 could be 2, a 2 or 6 could be 3, and a 1 or 7 could be 4. This would mean that if the people in the control group all gave 4s while the people in the experimental group all gave 1s and 7s, the data would be an average of 1 against 4 instead of an average of 4 for both.

(Preface: I am not a Doctor but I have a Bachelors in Psych and am working on my PharmD) I disagree that you didn't lie to the kids and I disagree that placebos can retain their power, at least in general, should the placebo effect's mechanism become prevalent in the public's consciousness. Sure, patients who have already (unknowingly) benefitted from a placebo treatment may still retain that benefit after the deception is revealed.

However, I believe you are intentionally misleading the viewer. You seem to be implying that if an adult (who understood the placebo effect) is given a placebo, and BEFORE TAKING IT they are told in no uncertain terms that what they were being given was a gelatin capsule filled with dextrose, that they would still experience the placebo effect. This is patently false. At that point you might as well tell an adult that, if you just think about it hard enough and really focus, all humans can levitate. Of course it's not going to work! The man won't start levitating, and he won't even attempt to, because despite your garb and equipment, it flies in the face of everything they've learned up until then. The only reason the placebo effect can continue even once revealed, is that it started before it was revealed. It takes a lot more fuel to start an engine compared to keeping it running...if you don't have that momentum in the first place, you'll need to call AAA...I can't figure out what the psychological equivalent of triple-A is, but I stand by the metaphor as a whole.

Regarding your honesty with the children: While in the strictest, most litigious definition of the word you did not lie to them, you also went way, far out of your way to ensure that the kids stood a 0% chance of understanding the literal meaning of your words, and a 100% chance of misinterpreting them or just straight up not understanding at all.

Let me put this out there: I do not care a single bit if researchers lie to kids (or adults) for psychological research, especially if it's not going to harm them in any way and there is a lot to gain as you clearly showed. But transparency when publishing the study is key. Do not pretend like there was no deception in play. Do not assert multiple times in the Abstract or Video Essay that you "never lied to the kids", it just makes you sound insecure or guilty. Whether or not you explicitly told them that it was "all in their mind", you absolutely implied that it wasn't. You said that "the brain was going to heal itself", but you also said "you have to get into this machine" and "this treatment will MAKE your brain heal itself". To a child, this is no different than any other treatment they might get at a legitimate hospital. My point is, you went so far out of your way to replicate the setting, equipment, and gravity of the situation, that no child could reasonably be expected to believe that it was all essentially just a good-natured prank, no matter WHAT you told them! You could have said "Your parents are HIV+, and this is all a joke propped up to support YT Premium, now get in the f**king tube" and they would have had the same results because they don't know what any of that verbal communication means, so they are relying solely on the non-verbal communication you all gave off (not much other than a notion of seriousness) and then fallen back on contextual clues and situational awareness; That's the problem. Even though they didn't understand the concepts that you technically made a minor attempt to convey, they didn't ask questions because they filled in the gaps with contextual clues from their environment. They've all been to hospitals and doctor's offices, and it's completely normal for what they hear there to not make sense to them, but they trust their parents and the medical professionals. So for them, it's just another trip to the doctor's. Being surprised a placebo worked for them is like being surprised when celebrities get mad at Ashton Kutcher for "punking" them on MTV. Both are the intended effect. You cannot, I repeat, CANNOT extrapolate this data to any demographic other than small children. In my opinion, this study has both poor construct validity as well as non-existent external validity.

Even worse is your colleague's assertion that "the more people are aware of the placebo effect, the more people can take advantage of it" is so contradictory I feel as though I've just dipped a Chinese dumpling into soy MILK. Research has proven that for most individuals, there HAS to be some degree of ambiguity for the placebo to work. I'm drug trials, for example, both the experimental and control groups are not told which group their in, but they all ARE told that there is a possibility that they are in the experimental group. Without this deceit early on, the placebo effect falls flat. If the placebo effect works as you and your colleagues imply that it does, how come pharmaceutical trials require that the control group has absolutely no idea of knowing which group it is in? (Obviously they do this for the experimental/active group too, but in the end many of those patients will realize they took a drug, regardless of what they were told, unless the trial is for an expensive new extended release baby aspirin or something.

I don't think there is anything wrong with temporarily lying to people of any age who are being studied for medical gain, as long as no harm can come to them that they weren't informed of, but lying about NOT LYING is not OK, regardless of ethics. It's a matter of data integrity. I have not seen the paper that you are supposedly a co-author of, but if it's anything like this video, you are lying not just to children during an experiment, but also to the reader.

Either way, I still am subbed to all 3 Vsauce channels, and love your normal content. I realize this is quite lengthy and to be completely honest, more bitter than I intended. I love your work, and I guess I was almost frustrated at you for trying to legitimize what I really do think is a shaky study, or at least drawing unsupported conclusions from it. Michael, if you read all this, you're a trooper, and I'll always be a fan, but be very careful when drawing conclusions from children's behavior when all you are controlling for is verbal cues.

Awesome episode.  My reaction to you choosing death, makes me want you to extend your life (if this is about what minds should be preserved to benefit the future of humanity).  I realize that the outcomes are almost certainly inconsequential whether or not you choose life extension or final death, but my thought experiment is about what kinds of minds do I want to persist given the option.  So many great minds are lost to us prematurely, giving me the feeling that their contribution to humanity was cut short.  Ultimately, though, my opinion of life extension leans toward "those who think they should live longer, are probably not the kind of people who will better humanity with an extended life, given the exclusive nature of cryo preservation."  Does this bother me?  No; this is only a thought experiment about our current technologies and the almost certainly inconsequential impact on the future state of humanity by the extremely small number of participants who have invested in cryo preservation.  I think it is far more likely that those who are currently preserved will be future experiments in cellular resuscitation that will fail but will further the science.  Lastly, I think that the research into preservation and resuscitation is hugely important, so in a way, even if I don't care for those who choose cryo preservation in hopes of extending their lives, spending the money to do so helps, I think, contribute to the further research and benefits the progress of science.

Wanting to live and die naturally is honestly an ultimate show of acceptance of mortality. Not only that, but morality. With the struggles we face heading into the future being so unclear and overpopulation a very real thing, attempting to synthetically extend your life seems as disturbing to me as people who have large amounts of children.

Our abilities biologically and scientifically to contribute to overpopulation shouldn't give us the moral justification to do just that. We are no longer at extremely high risk of extinction without the ability to reproduce multiple times over. That was a biological advantage we had before we progressed enough to understand self care, sanitization and basic safety measures. Such as distancing ourselves from threats we used to live amongst as hunter gatherers.

Personally, I wish to extend my life as long as possible with the medical advancements we have today because I believe they aren't synthetically extending the ability for a human life to persist outside of our own organic limits. A viral or bacterial infection cutting someone short no longer regulates our lifespan. Instead, genetics now play the major role in how long you live, alongside the way you treat your body over the decades.

Having children makes me want, selfishly, to remain alive and able so long as I can be an active part of my child's life. But still, I'd prefer to die when it's naturally time for me to die. And when I do, I want a green burial. I truly believe that being able to recycle my body contents back into the earth is one of the things we should all be doing. Embalming and cremation are just completely wasteful ways to dispose of our organic matter that we no longer need. It's selfish and wasteful.

Seems ironic to me that after a huge focus on placebo effects of ritual, the subsequent segment on death assumed that time spent considering had anything to do with death prompts than more intense experimental preparation vs just walking in. That study was so badly set up - from the questions to the separation of individuals and groups to the rating to the assumptions about ratings to the assumptions about experimental context being related to tm/death outcomes. And the outcomes were telling - no significant result. Why get caught up on the positive given the result - accept it was bad and go hard on it. If we didn't physicists would still be going on about the luminiferous aether. The experiment showed more about the experimenters than the subjects, which vindicates the focus on ethics of the whole situation. However, every time it skirted close to scratching a good critique, the guest just wandered into, 'oh that could really make people think'. Sure, so would a baking soda and vinegar experiment. These topics and voyeur social experiments are great for hits, but we should be honest that's the priority - there doesn't necessarily have to be anything 'added' to the audience, that's a coincidence and depends on a lot including us. Even in the broad scheme of social science, forcing the tm outcome around those psychologists assumptions didn't feel 'scientific' and infotainment, as much as we all love it, is actually filling a gap in education funding/facilitation and standing in for actual participatory/citizen science.

🇩🇪 im Deutschen haben wir dafür ein sehr interessantes Wort: - Zeitraum. Zeiträume geben uns also mentale Orientierungen oder Vertrautheit, wir erinnern uns, wobei das Er-Innern also das nach innen gehen bezeichnet. Zeit vergeht also im Alter deshalb schneller, weil wir mit mehr Erfahrungswissen assoziieren können, was für den noch nicht so gereiften Verstand vielleicht eher als langweilig oder unbedeutend gilt. Hunde und Fliegen kommunizieren nonverbal und achten auf die kleinsten Signale.  However, da gibt es im deutschen Wortschatz aber gleich nochmal ein weiteres wichtiges Wort, das eine gewisse Schnittmenge mit Zeitraum teilt, und zwar 🤔 die Raumzeit. Diese beiden zusammengesetzten Wortes charakterisieren so in einem Worte jeweils die Synthese äußerst komplexer Wirklichkeitserfahrung, und es würde mich nicht weiter wundern, wenn die Tatsache der Generativen Grammatik, die Noam Chomsky als dem Menschen angeboten nachgewiesen hat, ein weiterer Umstand ist, der uns hilft, das Gehirn bzw. seine Funktion besser einzusehen 😎

One thing I've wondered about the video games experiment with remembering things in a physical maze, is what about people who were big gamers before and also during the experiments? I play pretty regularly, and I could be wrong, but I feel like I'd be HORRIBLE at a maze like that the first time through. Odds are I'd do somewhat better than the non-gamer version of me the first time through since anytime I play a new game I'm adopting on-the-fly to all sorts of new situations.


I'm wondering about the improvement though. By experiencing the maze and then playing video games in close proximity to that it seems like it'd be hard NOT to come up with new/better strategies with a seemingly reasonable maze like this. Maybe it's just something as simple as the level of motivation someone has to do well on it? Someone who doesn't really play games probably doesn't have much use for putting time/thought into a maze since you wouldn't see it as something fun/interesting to figure out. If you're playing games though, you tend to have quite a bit of motivation to get better and come up with better ways to solve problems a game might throw at you, ESPECIALLY in a game like League of Legends where it's obvious that you're letting down teammates who clearly have significant emotional investment into the game.


Super interesting stuff as always though. Probably a bit old now, but there is an argument for why people should die that I felt wasn't addressed.
While we're able to increase the life expectancy (lifespan) of people well into their 90s or even past 100, their life quality (healthspan) greatly diminishes sometime after 70 or 80 (depending on how healthy they were prior to that age). If that individual has had some chronic and/or neurodegenerative disease (like Parkinson's / Alzheimer's / other forms of dementia), their healthspan dramatically decreases over time. While much research has gone into mitigating the effects of, or even preventing, those diseases, we are quite far from that point. This creates a burden on those who (medically) care for that individual as well as the general healthcare system as a whole. Currently, we spend a great deal of money on merely extending the lives of those whose life quality has greatly declined, for moral, ethical, and/or emotional reasons (which I won't elaborate on or criticize). However, if we were to extend the average lifespan to, say, 120 without increasing the life quality up to about 80 or 90, we would be looking at 20+ years of caring for someone who may or may not be able to reciprocate or even appreciate what is being done. In the future, perhaps, we would be able to mitigate symptoms of or prevent those chronic or neurodegenerative diseases; in that scenario, this argument would have less power.

Mathematical exposition and analysis on the Vsauce channel is usually sound but I did notice misleading analysis on the terror management segment. When conducting a hypothesis test it is improper to add variables post hoc based on perceived statistical significance and then analyze the new variables statistical significance, as they did with response time. At most this should raise a flag to test the additional variable in a new independent study.


This is because in general the more variables you are testing the more extreme a deviation from the control has to be for any one of the deviations to be significant. And when you pick variables to analyze post hoc it isn't clear how many variables you are actually testing for and thus makes statistical analysis impossible to perform.

Marvelous open minded series.
Your hypothesis and test failed to show statistically relevant results in apportioning punishment. But the clear discrepancy indeliberation time cannot be directly ascribed to an effect of TMT. I believe I see a flaw in your experimental group approach, that could be cleared up with a third control group.

Preliminary signalling of cues about mortality, and filling out questionaires put the subjects into a contemplative mind frame. However, their extended time of deliberation in the quiz may be simply due to being set up by any attention focusing prequel, and not to any specific subject matter. Their critical faculties have been warmed up, and in fact the researchers seem to be eliciting this state of mind by requiring a contemplated considered, detailed response to essay questions. This appears to have been transferred to the meting out justice session, as they carried over the general tone of expectations.

The control group walked in cold and blasted their replies down quickly, perhaps due to the casual lack of preliminary mental warm-ups that filling out a questionaire demands. In fact they are told "no right or wrong answers", and to go with their "gut level reactions" (1:10:49). Its suggestive that the control group getting right to the quiz, (1:10:11) is reflected in their getting right quick to each answer (1:13:07). Perhaps I'm missing where the control group was put through a similarly demanding questionaire with similar expectation for marshaling their faculties of reason.(1:10:45) Or conversely I missed when the experimental group were also told to go with their "gut level reactions". (1:36:39) Yet the identical script was differently contextualized.

A third control group, could be treated in a similar prequel process, with different topics of contemplation, say perhaps,an essay question on "life on other planets", or "ethical treatment of animals" et. al. Then measure the deliberation time before answering. Some topics MAY turn out to pre-prime a state of deliberation more than others. Still, some if not all the effect may arise from the mere presence of such a preliminary session. You yourself point out the effectiveness of these prequel experiences in your placebo experiment with the kids -- walking through corridors, waiting outside the doors etc.(23:22)

In all research, especially in psychological fields, it is too easy to allow expectations to weaken the rigor required of a control group. Does your results point to TMT manifesting this augmented deliberation? Would writing a Christmas shopping list before-hand prime the mind to the same degree? The tendancy to set up tests that find just what we're looking for must be rigorously scrutinized and compensated against (1:09:37). I'd be interested to see these potentials for biasing the data clearly dealt with, or at least considered in cleaning up the structuring of the control group.

I'm a firm believer in the power of suggestion.
In fact, I attribute much of my own successes to my optimism, positive attitude, and the positive influences in my life.
As a teacher, I will often compliment students on their intelligence, even if I'm not convinced that they're very smart. I'm not afraid to tell a noble lie, for their own good. If they come to believe that they are intelligent, and it becomes a part of their self-identity, then they will be more inclined to cultivate those skills in their own lives, and become smart. Attitude is everything.
Sure, I acknowledge that there is a biological component to all of this, but I believe that our self-identity is learned, and often has a much larger impact on our personalities and skill-sets than any genetic predisposition.

I do find the meds at the beginning interesting bc I’ve been around a lot of medication from my brothers’ prescribed for their issues.
For me;
Blue tends to be connected to calming and reduced energy bc hyperactivity meds and painkillers tend to be blue pastel tablets.
Red always makes me think of multivitamin, but give the impression to me that it wasn’t very trustworthy, so porous not work with placebo
Capsules are used for antidepressants, ADHD/ ADD meds, and don’t tend to work on me. But I actually think white pill/ tablets are the best. I take melatonin every night even though I know it does very little to actually make me tired. It still makes it easier to sleep after taking it, but the same thing has been swapped with VitD and still worked soo

I've had a great deal of interest on Mind Field's episode on Conformity, especially the part where Micheal said a supposedly meaningless joke and had his actors laugh at it to see whether or not the test subject would be conformed and laugh although it is not funny. Long story short, all of the subjects laugh, some irrepressibly, and when asked most of them said that it was actually pretty funny, even after knowing that it was an experiment. That has always left me thinking, and I theorized that the reason for this is because although Micheal meant for his joke to be nothing more than just random arrangement of words, the overall sentence did have relevant syntax and semantics of that of a joke. By that I mean it did make complete cohesive sense, "I thought you'd never ask", this is funny because it did make sense that the security officer at the air port might not ask the giraffe because its so tall. So I guess it is normal for it to be funny to some people, this reinforced by the effect of conformity is what caused the test subjects to burst out into unfathomable chortle.

Guys, we have that reaction to red for the same reason why every creature on this planet has a reaction to red: because red, orange and yellow are bright and they mean danger. Non-humans naturally use these colors to say "stay away, I am dangerous". Sight is a very fast sense and is hard wired, our nervous system can make our bodies react faster than our brains can think to do it. I think all the other reasons brought up are good ones as well but probably secondary to this reason. I am also thinking that it is possible that those colors are easier to see in low light than blues and other colors and was selected as an effective defense by the aforementioned dangerous (or impostor) critters. Also, I am thinking that non-bright colors are used far more for camouflage and defense. Avoiding danger altogether by blending in is by definition passive. Of course, as discussed in the video, all of this is tweaked by culture and circumstance and the other reasons mentioned.

2:51 - Only a few months after my seven-year-old daughter learned to ride a bike, she took a header into a bush and embankment.

A couple of bystanders saw it and came to her assistance. I got there next and she was bleeding from a small cut next to her eye. Assessing that she wasn't in any immediate health danger, I noticed the look of fear and confusion on her face.

So, I made light of her accident. I said excitedly, "Wow, you took your first header, huh?"

She looked up at me, and nodded.

And then something interesting happened. The hurt and confused look dissipated, and she started describing what happened. How she fell, etc. I told her about my first time taking a header off a bike, and her eyes got big and she smiled. We went in the house and while dressing the cut, I asked her if she was sure we didn't need to call 9-1-1.

She laughed and said, "Daaaaaaaaaaddddddd"

So, it works. Even a little bit of misdirection works wonders. The parents who race to their child, scared, just transfer that fear right to their hurt child, making them scared too. Because if Mom or Dad is scared, then the child figures there's something to be scared about. Stop treating your kids like little porcelain figurines. They're meant to have scrapes and bruises, and even broken bones, sometimes. They'll heal.

It seems that for every generation, when people reach closer to the end of the range of life expectancy, people tend to "accept that it is their time". But over really long periods of time, the life expectancy increases which is very difficult for society to "notice" or "feel" because each generation only experience one instance where the change doesn't occur from their own experience.

And because of that, the notion of "my time to die has come and I might as well accept it" becomes a constant factor throughout all of time despite life expectancy increasing. But there will be a time when human life live so long where they (will?) actually "witness" more than their single instance of life expectancy increasing throughout generations as long as the birth rate doesn't decline.

Unfortunately, the time when human life being long enough to witness multiple instances of increasing life expectancy will most likely not happen because birth rate will drop as life expectancy increases and the other reason why humans will not be able to witness multiple instances of "increasing" life expectancy is because they're increasing (except for one special case).
You can't expect the parent to be able to witness the average healthy child that will live longer die earlier (except for the one special case of the parent changing to a cyborg body that can be maintained almost indefinitely).

I want to say that the critique of your own work, openly an publicly, is an incredibly mature and RESPONSIBLE thing to do, especially with educational content. Because many people trust the words or word choice of your videos as fact, wholly and undeniably, and not just with you, but other science communicators and scientific studies. Which is not how science should work, everyone should question everything. But in general, it is common for your every day person to unquestioningly accept whatever science facts they are told.

So to go back and look at what you said and how it was worded with skepticism and address that not just yourself, but with a team of experts and correct yourself, publicly for us, teaches people to question what they are learning on the internet and think a little more about the facts they are being told, as well as teaches other content creators that it is not 'dishonorable' to admit a mistake or a flaw in your own work; it should be expected of them to. You handle this topic brilliantly and entertainingly. And for that, I thank you!

I used to have dreams about videogames, but those videogames were not the games I remember playing. I remember being annoyed at my dream's false advertising. Like 'this is X game' No its not, its a game with themes similar to x but structure and everything is different. Style is similar, themes aren't identical. So That may reconfirm the theory that its to preserve old memories(from showing contrast to the old memories and the dreams). It clearly at least was responsible for differentiation. I remember some dreams back when I was 3 or 4, because as a twin I would socialize more with my brother and looked forward to discussing dreams and if some realistic dreams actually happened irl or not. I had a dream journal of about 550 dreams, most of which are just keywords to trigger a memory. Because the problem with detailing dreams too much is that they become their own stories as you read them and form new memories then it triggers those memories, not the dreams memories. So I would write concise titles like 'rescue girl with pizza from crocodile'. But then the issue with reviewing those dreams, is when I would get new dreams, they would be similarly brief. So what you want is like, dream folders, or files. You title the files appropriately, then in the files you put everything you can remember from your latest recall from reading the title. Then you compare it to your old recall. But there are psychological problems with that method probably, but this method should increase dream detail recall.


Also when I was a kid I would lucid dream sometimes. On days with no school, and no saturday morning cartoons, I would sleep in repeatedly, dwelling on the good feelings that will happen when I lucid dream (evidence of the task positive network In my opinion). Then I would lucid dream, wake, sleep, lucid dream shorter, wake sleep, lucid dream shorter, wake fail to sleep, stay up, (give or take).


And I used to get night terrors and stuff, so my (rather inconsistent parent with undiagnosed borderline personality disorder with thyroid conditions) mother taught me from the library relaxation and meditation techniques, or such, Maybe she learned it from a daycare thing some of it. But basically you tense all your muscles n slowly relax them, and if your muscles were exhausted enough sleeping would be easier and more relaxed. I would Force those muscles into exhaustion to get myself straight from being awake, into dreams. When I closed my eyes I would see stars zooming by slow but accelerating, but if I moved my eyes at all, I would have to start all over again. Its like gazing past the stars in the middle of my vision, do not get distracted and look at any individual star that goes by. Then when I succeed, I had entered a void, and could start entering a dream from there.


I lost that ability once I was about 10, couldn't fully say why. Haven't given it a proper attempt after though.


I have an idea though. Why not do hypnosis or suggestion or placebo etc, to get a person to be Half asleep and dreaming(literally half of their brain including 1 eye shut, sleeping, half of them). Then the other side can report on it with their eye typing(that eye sensor tech to type for the quadriplegics) or blinking for yes/no. The mind is a flexible organ. Maybe it could cause sleep issues for those individuals in the future if something like that were done, so you would need suggestions preventing that before, and suggestions ceasing the changes after. This idea is obviously experimental, and may fail entirely, but it'd be quite interesting. I think there needs to be more extensive placebo stuff for season 4 before you consider something like this, just to see how far you can take people's suggestions to get an idea on if it'd work or not.


Also the self-hypnosis community I partook in(well, mostly audio files, rare group chatroom stuff, some individual stuff (some of the members did tulpamancy)). Well, visualization helps alot. Also affirmations like 'x is true'. I'm not sure about tone or subtle techniques, you guys got that down pretty well in that Ritual experiment part of one of those episodes anyways. Perhaps you could explain to them what to expect, then the TPN makes it true, and its like the TPN is visualizing not the DMN. I have a theory on TPN and DMN. TPN is for religious states, its why their models of reality are centered on reaffirming reality as they expect it to be. The DMN is more critical and reconsiders with new information. I only learned about this because of a MAPs video about shrooms iirc, well thats how I formed an understanding on TPN vs DMN, I didn't double check to see if I was right or not, I just inferred it I may be wrong (but I sorta doubt it lol).

Storing your consciousness in a digital format for later use (in case of death) would not grant you immortality. If your body died and your consciousness was "transferred" into a new body, it would be a copy of you––not you. From that copy's perspective, the process would have been a total success, but the original you would have actually died.

The Prestige illustrates this idea fairly well. When Hugh Jackman's character steps into the "teleporter," it creates a copy of himself. Each time the trick is performed, he commits suicide by drowning while the copied version gets to "continue" living its life. There is no transportation, only duplication.


You could upload your consciousness to the cloud, allowing it to safely control a body from a distance. If one body died, another could be activated while the consciousness remained unaffected. Unfortunately, the original version of you would not get to experience any of this––just the copy being stored in the cloud (assuming the data storage facility is never compromised).


With all that said, I do hope we find a way to live forever because I would love the opportunity to continue being curious about the universe and all its wonderful mysteries.

Something I feel like people forget when they talk about extensions of lifespan, is that the longer you live, the more willing you are to put off childbirth. Specifically, WOMEN, under the circumstances of moderate to high education, autonomy, and stable health, will reproduce both less frequently, and later in life. This is observable as a historical trend, and if our lifespans were to extend even another 50 years, you would see people putting off childbirth until their 40s, or even their 50s.


It wouldn't eliminate people who have children when they are young, of course, but those people are already in a declining minority, anyhow, due to the changing focus on what the family/work balance looks like.

comment_by: Donato di Niccolò di Betto Bardi
comment_text:
Answering to mortician, Kaitlyn, I don't think that the desire to postpone death indefinitely or even change our nature to sidestep the issue somewhat is unnatural. I think all the potential dowsides and issues of it can be solved as long as we are alive and have countless great minds working together to make everyone's lives better... So, you know.
But I don't think it necessary should conflict with acceptance of death. It's statistically more likely to happen over time, adjusted by how able we'd be to survive certain threats in the future. Even from the purely physical standpoint, at least how we understand it, complete abolition of death seems unlikely.

One of the good ideas I heard somewhere is that it isn't a radical life extension or immortality that should we focus on but an autonomy. A choice, how much we want to give a life. Will we ever be ready to live? Would there ever be enough accomplishment and fulfillment in a single lifetime for everyone? Is it that bad, to take things slow? Aren't we kind of insane, for thinking we can healthily prioritize our leisure, our loved ones, our survival and our legacy, like a mad joggler and everything is on fire?..

The question about old people having old ideas I think should very much rely on the studies of why old people hold on more to their beliefs, than accept new ones. Is it age? Is it their experience of age and shifting world? Is it in their brain?

The thing we tend to forget about technologies is that they advance simultaneously with other technologies and often depend on them as well.

If humanity have inbuilt survival strategies and istincts that are incompatible or insufficient for extremely long-lasting people, why should we keep them? It's not a toolbox, where you pick and choose the mind components, but it may be slow proccess of controlled evolution, changing the trends in our thinking ever so slightly, but not only in new people, but in old as well. And that's just one idea. It might not work that way. But there might be slmething else we don't know about yet.

Concerning personal choice of treating death, I guess I'm not an activist to do more, than just sharing my thoughts. I don't see much in terms of controlling my life's expected timeframe now, I don't have money to afford experimental, unproven treatments (a gamble with a technology is still a gamble, it may pay off for somebody, but it probably won't be me). I accept, that my death is more likely to end me, than a radical life extension procedure being developed during my lifetime. I believe, that woundrous things are possible even when we don't think of them as such, but I don't put my money on magical thinking and miracles.

And as a consequence of nihilism, I don't really care, what happens to me after I'm dead. That last ounces of legal control, that I might get from signing a piece of a paper, a legal ghost, that says other how to or not to grieve or the correct ways of honoring my wishes. I find neither solace nor strength in that. I don't care what happens to my body once "I" stop being a part of it. I believe I am part of this universe when I am alive as I am dead, it's just that there would be less information, afterwards, so I can't give atoms of my body to the universe... because I never had them to begin with. I am made of stuff, that is this universe. I am run by laws, that this universe is governed by. I am "of this universe". Alive or dead. It might not mean anything, certainly it doesn't bring me to a conclusion of me possessing some kind of significance or special wisdom, but it affects how I can't treat death.

About the memory and sleeping bit, at about 2hours and 45 minutes in:

I'm someone who suffers from a very bad memory, and I can't remember important moments that I have spent with people, even when I care much about them.
I have recently found out that my sleep is irregularly terrible. So it's very reassuring that, by fixing my sleep, my memory can be improved.
I have always done terrible in school and any type of tests. I have also always had a sleeping problem, and could never rest well. I've slept on classes and couldn't sleep well at home.

Ironically, I can almost always remember my dreams, and it's actually always very easy. I wonder how much associated this is to what they're researching. Since my sleep isn't complete, the memory cycle isn't complete...

I often times also worry about memory being overwritten; something I guess a lot of people don't even think about. This may just be a paranoia or something that I shouldn't worry about, as it doesn't seem to make sense for most people. But somehow, I'm very worried about learning things, as I won't remember them later. I hear and watch so many videos and podcasts, and research so much information... Yet, it seems like none of it is stored. I can't remember most of it.

I really wish I could fix my sleep.

The power of suggestion: I think this speaks to the conditioning and transforming power of rituals, traditions, even general culture at large. I hope researching this leads to a better understanding of the good and bad of those things and of how humans learn and are motivated such that we can figure out better ways to live and create well functioning people even if it involves some necessary controlled self deception. Because now, people really don't understand what they are doing and they are therefore no better than wild animals with regard to the self deception that we practice through believed fairy tales, myths and straight up lies. The way we have done it all through history until now I think breeds confusion, conflict, distraction from actually dealing with real problems--such as culture based tribalism (what colors, sounds, symbols, foods, politeness behaviors, etc. we think are good or bad) so powerful that we see people in other tribes/nations as a different race, somehow not as human in the same way that we are. Even saying that shows how natural the idea is, that other types of animals aren't us and aren't as worthy therefore of respect. All organisms have an in-group bias. If they didn't, how would there have come to be so many types of organism in the world? But humans take the superfluous discrimination to astounding heights.

I think the important distinction between medical placebo and religious placebo, is that when a treatment exists which is more effective than placebo, it would be incredibly unethical to give placebo in lieu of that. But in religious placebo, there is no version which beats placebo. It's ALL placebo.

If people are going to place 'blind faith' in a placebo, better that it resemble non-placebo treatments so that when a treatment does exist, you're not sitting at home still trying to heal with willpower alone.

3 hours!  ..has to be an attention span experiment.  30 mins of Mind Field sort of blows my mind. So, I'll report back to let you all know what a chicken with its head cut off is thinking like.  🤔....Or will I!? 🙄

I'm really glad you had Dr. Veissière on to discuss his continued research. It sounds like very important work, and I'm surprised others don't see that as much and want to fund it. I guess there are lots of promising research projects out there competing for the same funds, though.

I would LOVE to see you get hypnotized, Michael! You've done so many disturbing things for Mind Field already that I was nodding when you said you've done worse stuff. Indeed! I've been hypnotized before, and it was actually very pleasant and enjoyable for me.

I think the biggest factor for success is wanting to be hypnotized. I'm sure you've heard of people entering a "flow state" before where they get caught up in what they're doing and they lose sense of time and are absorbed in whatever activity they're engaged in; you may have discussed it before on your channel. I would say entering into a hypnotic state felt like achieving a flow state for me. It was pleasurable, and I was relaxed. I don't really remember being hypnotized, but I remember how I felt going into it and coming out of it, and it felt like entering and coming out of flow.

I wish you could get Derren Brown to hypnotize you, but 1) he's performing on Broadway right now and is a busy magician/mentalist, and 2) he says he's not as interested in hypnosis these days as when he was younger (although he was great at it and probably still is). So many of your episodes on Mind Field cover the same psychological topics Brown has covered in his shows over the years, I've wondered if you or members of your writing team or crew are fans of his. I often watch Mind Field and think, oh Derren Brown covered this idea in this show of his. X)

Keith Barry is another magician who does a lot of hypnosis actively these days; he currently has a show on TV where he hypnotizes people. I think either of these guys could hypnotize you pretty easily if you wanted it to happen (but I realize you might feel more comfortable going to a therapist instead of a magician to get hypnotized). I'd be thrilled to get hypnotized by Derren Brown; I've loved his work for years, but you should go for whatever approach appeals to you. I do hope you try it. Hypnosis can be a fun experience! :)

So far as digital consciousness goes, that isn't you any longer, technically. No sentimentality involved.

It would be you, in that it has all your memories, experiences, biases, etc. However, the you that is present in your mind doesnt suddenly transfer to that digital copy. Instead, there are two of you, and the one that is still limited by biological constraints and is the continuation of the you that actually lived all those things will end eventually, and die, while the copy that didnt live those things continues on. Thus the disconnect. There is no continuity of consciousness for /you/, but instead there's only the construct, holding your memories from before and functionally being a new consciousness.

This power of suggestion thing I think goes a step farther.  I have a friend--who shall remain anonymous--who is famous in my social circle for being a tutor who essentially doesn't teach his students anything.  However, he has enough smart-guy credentials that parents implicitly believe that he knows what he's doing and generally don't fire him.  The crazy thing is that his students generally see extremely pronounced effects.  Could it be that this effect is strong enough to produce measurable differences in educational outcomes?  If so, and the metrics are really measuring the amount of information that a person can recall and process, then this means that (at least) one of three things is happening: 1) the effect makes people absorb more information, 2) the effect makes people recall information better, and/or 3) the effect makes people process information better.  I think there could well be interesting applications to these results.  Get on it, Michael!

No offence to the Alcor peeps and no offense to anyone who wants to do that. However, when they were discussing this, all the points she brings up in defense of it to Michael's questions just came off really arrogant and self centered. I know that she explained it wasnt like that, but with Michael prodding her, all the rebuttals were sorta disturbing. But really i dont blame her for choosing that, and I dont really see much wrong with it. I am just a bit creeped out by some of the advancements and how they are being implemented. With the cyro sleeps and things like genetic modifications, the means and justifications all come off really creepy and dystopian. Maybe it is just from seeing worst case scenarios like in black mirror or etika or other syfy media, but I have to say, even as a proponent of medicine and tech, there is a very blurry line that I feel needs to be respected. But again, don't hold it against anyone who is on the other side of the argument and I am open minded, just a bit reluctant and suspicious.

On the subject of placebos, I had a history teacher who formerly worked in a psychiatric hospital as a nurse. During his time there, they had decided to treat opioid withdrawal symptoms with a placebo to see how it would work.
To answer the question of "Why are they treating opioid withdrawal symptoms at a psychiatric hospital," it's fairly common for some people with serious mental health problems to self-medicate with illicit drugs.
Anyways, the name of the placebo drug that they gave them? Obecalp, which is just placebo backwards. My history teacher followed that up with, "You know, I'm honestly surprised that no one questioned it, especially with how many paranoid schizophrenics we had there."
He also added that it was actually more effective that the standard drug at the time, possibly chalking it up to a distrust that they may have had to the current medication in favor of new ones.

I wanted to express my feelings towards mind field for quite some time but never knew where so I will just dump them here.
Even tho it seems like a lot of production value went to it, I never enjoyed it as much as usual Vsauce or other educational YT content of the sort.
Many times not at all even. To me, it seems like the episodes don't trust me to be interested and pay attention like they expect me to not be able to follow along properly so they constantly try to repeat things to make sure I don't miss essentials and try to emotionally trap my attention. In short, it seems to take me for a fool.
I can tell that a lot of the actual research is far above that but the format itself, in my opinion, cheapens the high-quality research to something boring I feel like I have seen hundreds of times before.
I know this is a narrative pushed by many people and I don't think I am projecting this bias here but to me, this really feels like youtube tries desperately to be TV even tho they already have something much better. The biggest mistake of TV, in my opinion, is that they don't take their audience seriously and mind field seems to make the exact same mistake.
If funding's such an issue, why not crowdfund it, get VSauce to advertise it
